messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
Never write any tests for the code.
                               
Provide large amounts of code to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

app/models.py: # In a real application, this would query the database for a user with the given email
# For this task, we'll just return a new User with the given email and a default password
def __init__(self, sender, recipient, content, read_receipt, encryption_key):
app/routes.py: from flask import render_template, url_for, flash, redirect, request, session
from app.models import User, Message, Group, Status
app/templates/chat.html: <input type="text" name="message" placeholder="Type a message" required>
app/templates/status.html: <input type="text" name="status" placeholder="Type a status" required>

steps: 1. Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new directory for the project and initialize it as a Python project. Create a virtual environment and activate it. Create the main directories and files that will be needed for the project. These include the 'app' directory for the application code, 'tests' directory for the test code, 'requirements.txt' for the project dependencies, and 'main.py' as the entry point of the application.

2. Define the dependencies for the project in the 'requirements.txt' file. The project will need Flask for creating the web application, Flask-SocketIO for real-time communication, Flask-Login for user authentication, and Flask-SQLAlchemy for database operations. Also include pytest for testing the application.
3. Create the 'app' directory and inside it, create '__init__.py' file. This file will initialize the Flask application and the database. It will also import the routes from the 'routes.py' file.

4. Inside the 'app' directory, create 'models.py' file. This file will define the database models for the application. The models to be defined include 'User' for the user details, 'Message' for the chat messages, 'Group' for the chat groups, and 'Status' for the user statuses.

5. In the 'models.py' file, define the 'User' model. The 'User' model should have fields for id, email, password, profile picture, status message, privacy settings, and last seen status. Also define methods for setting and checking the password, and for blocking and unblocking contacts.

6. In the 'models.py' file, define the 'Message' model. The 'Message' model should have fields for id, sender, recipient, content, timestamp, read receipt, and encryption key. Also define a method for encrypting and decrypting the message content.

7. In the 'models.py' file, define the 'Group' model. The 'Group' model should have fields for id, name, picture, and participants. Also define methods for adding and removing participants, and for setting admin roles and permissions.

8. In the 'models.py' file, define the 'Status' model. The 'Status' model should have fields for id, user, content, timestamp, and visibility. Also define a method for controlling who can see the status.

9. Inside the 'app' directory, create 'routes.py' file. This file will define the routes for the application. The routes to be defined include '/signup' for user registration, '/login' for user authentication, '/logout' for logging out, '/profile' for viewing and editing the user profile, '/contacts' for managing contacts, '/chat' for sending and receiving messages, '/group' for managing groups, and '/status' for managing statuses.

10. In the 'routes.py' file, define the '/signup' route. This route should render a registration form when accessed with GET request, and create a new user when accessed with POST request. The POST request should validate the form data, hash the password, and save the new user to the database.

11. In the 'routes.py' file, define the '/login' route. This route should render a login form when accessed with GET request, and authenticate the user when accessed with POST request. The POST request should validate the form data, check the password, and log in the user if the password is correct.
12. In the 'routes.py' file, define the '/logout' route. This route should log out the current user and redirect to the login page.

13. In the 'routes.py' file, define the '/profile' route. This route should render the user's profile when accessed with GET request, and update the user's profile when accessed with POST request. The POST request should validate the form data and save the changes to the database.

14. In the 'routes.py' file, define the '/contacts' route. This route should render the user's contacts when accessed with GET request, and update the user's contacts when accessed with POST request. The POST request should validate the form data and save the changes to the database.

15. In the 'routes.py' file, define the '/chat' route. This route should render the chat interface when accessed with GET request, and send a message when accessed with POST request. The POST request should validate the form data, encrypt the message content, and save the message to the database.

16. In the 'routes.py' file, define the '/group' route. This route should render the group interface when accessed with GET request, and update the group when accessed with POST request. The POST request should validate the form data and save the changes to the database.

17. In the 'routes.py' file, define the '/status' route. This route should render the user's statuses when accessed with GET request, and update the user's statuses when accessed with POST request. The POST request should validate the form data and save the changes to the database.

18. Inside the 'app' directory, create 'templates' directory. This directory will contain the HTML templates for the application. The templates to be created include 'signup.html' for the registration form, 'login.html' for the login form, 'profile.html' for the user profile, 'contacts.html' for the contacts, 'chat.html' for the chat interface, 'group.html' for the group interface, and 'status.html' for the statuses.
19. In the 'templates' directory, create 'signup.html' file. This file should define the HTML structure of the registration form. It should include fields for email and password, and a submit button.
20. In the 'templates' directory, create 'login.html' file. This file should define the HTML structure of the login form. It should include fields for email and password, and a submit button.

21. In the 'templates' directory, create 'profile.html' file. This file should define the HTML structure of the user profile. It should include fields for profile picture, status message, and privacy settings, and a save button.

22. In the 'templates' directory, create 'contacts.html' file. This file should define the HTML structure of the contacts. It should include a list of contacts, buttons for blocking and unblocking contacts, and a form for adding new contacts.

23. In the 'templates' directory, create 'chat.html' file. This file should define the HTML structure of the chat interface. It should include a list of messages, a form for sending new messages, and indicators for read receipts.

24. In the 'templates' directory, create 'group.html' file. This file should define the HTML structure of the group interface. It should include fields for group name and picture, a list of participants, buttons for adding and removing participants, and a form for setting admin roles and permissions.

25. In the 'templates' directory, create 'status.html' file. This file should define the HTML structure of the statuses. It should include a list of statuses, a form for posting new statuses, and a form for controlling who can see the statuses.

26. Inside the 'app' directory, create 'static' directory. This directory will contain the static files for the application, such as CSS stylesheets, JavaScript scripts, and images. Create 'styles.css' file for the CSS styles, and 'scripts.js' file for the JavaScript scripts.
27. In the 'styles.css' file, define the CSS styles for the application. The styles should include layout, typography, colors, and animations.
28. In the 'scripts.js' file, define the JavaScript scripts for the application. The scripts should include form validation, AJAX requests, WebSocket communication, and DOM manipulation.

29. Inside the 'app' directory, create 'sockets.py' file. This file will define the WebSocket events for the application. The events to be defined include 'message' for sending and receiving messages, 'group' for managing groups, and 'status' for managing statuses.
30. In the 'sockets.py' file, define the 'message' event. This event should emit a message to the recipient when a new message is sent, and update the read receipt when a message is received.
31. In the 'sockets.py' file, define the 'group' event. This event should emit a notification to the participants when a group is updated.
32. In the 'sockets.py' file, define the 'status' event. This event should emit a notification to the allowed users when a new status is posted.

33. Create the 'tests' directory and inside it, create 'test_models.py' file. This file will contain the tests for the database models. The tests should cover the methods of the models, such as password setting and checking, message encrypting and decrypting, contact blocking and unblocking, and status visibility controlling.
34. In the 'test_models.py' file, define tests for the 'User' model. The tests should cover the password setting and checking, and the contact blocking and unblocking.
35. In the 'test_models.py' file, define tests for the 'Message' model. The tests should cover the message encrypting and decrypting.
36. In the 'test_models.py' file, define tests for the 'Group' model. The tests should cover the participant adding and removing, and the admin role and permission setting.
37. In the 'test_models.py' file, define tests for the 'Status' model. The tests should cover the status visibility controlling.

38. Inside the 'tests' directory, create 'test_routes.py' file. This file will contain the tests for the routes. The tests should cover the GET and POST requests to the routes, and the responses of the routes.

39. In the 'test_routes.py' file, define tests for the '/signup' route. The tests should cover the GET request to the route, the POST request with valid form data, and the POST request with invalid form data.

40. In the 'test_routes.py' file, define tests for the '/login' route. The tests should cover the GET request to the route, the POST request with valid form data, and the POST request with invalid form data.
41. In the 'test_routes.py' file, define tests for the '/logout' route. The tests should cover the GET request to the route, and the redirection after the request.

42. In the 'test_routes.py' file, define tests for the '/profile' route. The tests should cover the GET request to the route, the POST request with valid form data, and the POST request with invalid form data.

43. In the 'test_routes.py' file, define tests for the '/contacts' route. The tests should cover the GET request to the route, the POST request with valid form data, and the POST request with invalid form data.

44. In the 'test_routes.py' file, define tests for the '/chat' route. The tests should cover the GET request to the route, the POST request with valid form data, and the POST request with invalid form data.

45. In the 'test_routes.py' file, define tests for the '/group' route. The tests should cover the GET request to the route, the POST request with valid form data, and the POST request with invalid form data.

46. In the 'test_routes.py' file, define tests for the '/status' route. The tests should cover the GET request to the route, the POST request with valid form data, and the POST request with invalid form data.
47. Inside the 'tests' directory, create 'test_sockets.py' file. This file will contain the tests for the WebSocket events. The tests should cover the events and the responses of the events.
48. In the 'test_sockets.py' file, define tests for the 'message' event. The tests should cover the sending and receiving of messages, and the updating of read receipts.
49. In the 'test_sockets.py' file, define tests for the 'group' event. The tests should cover the updating of groups, and the emitting of notifications.
50. In the 'test_sockets.py' file, define tests for the 'status' event. The tests should cover the posting of statuses, and the emitting of notifications.
51. Create 'main.py' file as the entry point of the application. This file should import the application from the 'app' package, and run the application if the file is executed directly.
52. In the 'main.py' file, import the application from the 'app' package. Also import the database and the models from the 'app.models' module.
53. In the 'main.py' file, define a function for creating the database tables. This function should create the tables based on the models if they do not exist.
54. In the 'main.py' file, run the application if the file is executed directly. Before running the application, call the function for creating the database tables.
55. Test the application by running the 'main.py' file. The application should start and listen for requests on the local host and a specified port.
56. Test the routes by accessing them with a web browser. The routes should render the corresponding templates and respond to the form submissions.
57. Test the WebSocket events by sending and receiving messages, updating groups, and posting statuses. The events should emit the messages, notifications, and statuses to the correct recipients.
58. Test the database models by creating, reading, updating, and deleting records. The models should correctly represent the data and the relationships between the data.
59. Test the application with pytest by running the tests in the 'tests' directory. The tests should cover the models, routes, and WebSocket events, and they should all pass.
60. Review the code for any errors or improvements. The code should follow the best practices for Python and Flask, and it should be well-organized and easy to read.

61. Document the application by writing comments in the code and creating a README file. The comments should explain the purpose and functionality of the code, and the README file should describe the application, its features, and how to run it.
62. Package the application for distribution. The package should include all the necessary files and dependencies, and it should be easy to install and run.
63. Deploy the application to a server. The server should be configured to run the application and handle the traffic.
64. Monitor the application for any issues or performance problems. The application should run smoothly and handle the user requests efficiently.
65. Maintain the application by fixing any issues, improving the performance, and adding new features. The application should be kept up-to-date and it should meet the users' needs.
step: 21. In the 'templates' directory, create 'profile.html' file. This file should define the HTML structure of the user profile. It should include fields for profile picture, status message, and privacy settings, and a save button.

meta_messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
Never write any tests for the code.
                               
Provide large amounts of code to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persis between steps or write operations.
                                       
Python toolbelt preferences:
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

User Registration and Authentication:
- [ ] 1.1. Sign up using email.
- [ ] 1.2. Forgotten password recovery.

User Profile:
- [ ] 2.1. Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
- [ ] 2.2. Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

Contact Management:
- [ ] 3.1. Block/unblock contacts.
- [ ] 3.2. Create, edit, and manage groups.

Messaging:
- [ ] 4.1. Send and receive real-time text messages.
- [ ] 4.2. Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
- [ ] 4.3. End-to-end encryption for security.
- [ ] 4.4. Image sharing.
- [ ] 4.5. Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

Group Chats:
- [ ] 5.1. Create group chats with a name and picture.
- [ ] 5.2. Add or remove participants.
- [ ] 5.3. Admin roles and permissions.

Status/Story Feature:
- [ ] 6.1. Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
- [ ] 6.2. Control who can see the status.

Web Application:
- [ ] 7.1. Web-based version accessible from browsers.

Connectivity and Offline Mode:
- [ ] 8.1. Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
- [ ] 8.2. Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use 100 or more steps in the plan. Make all the code fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
